subject: History
title: The Color Revolutions
description: A fast breakdown of The Color Revolutions for builders.

hook.text: In the 2000s, peaceful protests in former Soviet states toppled authoritarian regimesâ€”each named after a color.

buildup.text: Georgia's Rose Revolution (2003), Ukraine's Orange Revolution (2004), and Kyrgyzstan's Tulip Revolution (2005).

discovery.text: Citizens protested rigged elections using nonviolent tactics inspired by Gene Sharp's writings on civil resistance.

twist.text: Russia saw these as Western-backed coups and vowed to prevent more. Putin's foreign policy hardened in response.

climax.text: Some revolutions stuck; others reversed. Ukraine's ongoing struggle shows that democracy, once won, must be defended.

punchline.text: Winning a revolution is easier than keeping it.

quiz.question: How did Russia interpret the Color Revolutions?
options: As inspiring models for Russian democracy
As Western-backed coups threatening Russian influence
As irrelevant events in small neighboring states
